content:
‚úÖ Approved the contribution.
Comment: I hesitated if it was rather a clash or an easy puzzle. With python and the numpy lcm (or math.lcm) function it's clearly a clash. But if you have to create this function it's too long for a clash in my opinion.
So I validate as a (very) easy puzzle.

‚úÖ Approved the contribution.
Comment: The puzzle is well designed, making you manipulate the strings as well as finding the lcm of the length and overall well made

‚úÖ Approved the contribution.
Comment: Another good contribution from Lisa_loves_drawing_outputs ;)

Hi Lisa,

You probably should say in the statement that you can only use a repetition of the full name, you can see it by checking the expecting results but there's no rule against it in the statement.

For example with names AAAAA && BCD what is preventing the use of:
AAAAA
B        A
C        A
D        A
B        A
C        A
BCDBC

For Test 20, the following frame seems to satisfy the rules too (sorry that the characters are not aligned properly, but you get the idea). I think the rules need to be expanded to cover such a situation. Thanks.

MarciaMarciaM
S           a
a           r
l           c
v           i
a           a
d           M
o           a
r           r
S           c
a           i
l           a
vadorSalvador
I think it should be a coc, and I don't understand how it is possible to do it in 150 lines of code, I did it in 20.

Hi Remi --  Right.

I was attracted to this task because I didn't know how to solve it, initially, until I figured it out.
(So, I was pretty pleased with myself for solving it even though it took a good number of lines.)

I think I'm traumatized because some that I've proposed as clashes, people are saying that they're too hard for a clash so maybe I'm erring on the other side now.

I thought the example of wife with 6-letters and husband with 8 letters (for example) made it a bit complicated.
Question: did you have to do the LCM thing, or is there a way to avoid that??

Dang I hadn't thought about that!!
5DN1L, your insights and input are so valuable ; you see things we miss.

I'll have to consider if I want to allow that option or not.

Thank You Thank You !!

Thanks for the feedback.

I bristle against over-explaining.  I mean a name is the entire word by definition.  Lisa‚Äôs name is not Lis

But I‚Äôm open to be convinced otherwise if you (others) want to try. üòä

Thanks.

Haha, yes, you're not wrong about that :)
Thanks luigidaddy üò∫
Thanks.
Are you going to upload a cover picture for the puzzle?

Hey --
Thanks for the nudge on that.  I had totally forgotten.

I just now made and uploaded the banner-image with two things in mind:
(1) describe the desired product
(2) make 5DN1L laugh out loud

How did I do??
Oh wow :D I didn't notice the bottom message the first time, but I looked at the image again and... you succeeded!
Nice !!
By the way, there is an "Easter Egg" hidden in a validator on one of my other pending-puzzles that I did just for you.... If you are bored, go find it :)

Aww... I've tried but I'm not sure which validator you're referring to :P

There are many wonderfully created puzzles (including yours ;) ) on CodinGame, so I never get bored :D

Well I can‚Äôt make it toooo easy‚Ä¶.  Consider it a quest that I challenge you to üò∫

Hint : it might be a ‚Äúsecret‚Äù
Awwwww, found it! I must be too tired to read properly yesterday. Thank you very much for the easter egg!
I used the lcm (actually A*B/gcd(A,B) because i didn't know that it was "lcm" in english), but there is a function to calculate it (i'm sure there is in C# too).

I mean, that's some "matrix level" coding...  I mostly get it, but that's not intuitive (easy to understand) coding, for people doing "easy" puzzles.
So how about we agree that most people would require more than 20 and less than 150 lines of code. :)

I still somewhat agree with you that it's too easy for a classic puzzle but I also think it's too hard for a clash.  It lives in the uncanny valley of Codingame :)

Let's just let it simmer here for a bit and see what others say.

you might be able to read this, it's in python but should make sense:
{
some notes:
"String.__len__()" returns the length of the string.
"math.lcm(int_A, int_B)" returns the LCM of A and B, can be used with more then just 2 int's.
"print(String)" well speaks for it self, (it prints the String).
" String*int " well for example "AIR"*3 is the same as "AIRAIRAIR"
}

import sys, math
# get the inputs
wife = str(input()); husband = str(input())
# make a copy of inputs
top = wife
low = husband
# get the desired size
size = math.lcm(top.__len__(),low.__len__())
print(size,file = sys.stderr)
# stack the strings to desired size
top*=int(size/top.__len__())
low*=int(size/low.__len__())
# print the top
print(top)
# print the sides
for i in range(size):
    print(low[i] + " "*(size-2) + top[i])
# print the final line
print(low)

@luigidaddy -- I just noticed that the solution I wrote for this (in C#) is now gone, and instead is your python code !!

How did that happen, I wonder ?? -- Yikes!
Maybe he edited your contrib to test his solution instead of "test in ide" :joy:
